quiz.title: AP Physics C: Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3, Quiz 10: Power (Calculus Relationships)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Instantaneous power as dot product, Power as derivative of work, Constant acceleration power, Drag force power, Graphical interpretation, Elevator problems, Constant power kinematics, Units of power

questions.question: A motor pulls a block with a constant force $\vec{F} = 20\hat{i} + 10\hat{j}$ N. At a specific moment, the block's velocity is $\vec{v} = 3\hat{i} - 2\hat{j}$ m/s. What is the instantaneous power delivered by the motor?
questions.explanation: Instantaneous power is given by the dot product: $P = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{v} = F_x v_x + F_y v_y = (20)(3) + (10)(-2) = 60 - 20 = 40$ W. The negative $v_y$ component reduces power because the force and velocity have opposite y-directions.

questions.question: The work done by a machine as a function of time is $W(t) = 2t^3 + 5t$. What is the instantaneous power at $t = 2$ seconds?
questions.explanation: Power is the time derivative of work: $P(t) = \frac{dW}{dt}$. Here, $\frac{d}{dt}(2t^3 + 5t) = 6t^2 + 5$. Evaluating at $t=2$: $P(2) = 6(2)^2 + 5 = 6\times4 + 5 = 24 + 5 = 29$ W.

questions.question: An object of mass $m$ starts from rest and accelerates with constant acceleration $a$. How does the instantaneous power $P$ delivered to the object vary with time $t$?
questions.explanation: With constant acceleration, velocity $v = at$. The net force is constant: $F = ma$. Power $P = Fv = (ma)(at) = ma^2 t$. Thus, power increases linearly with time ($P \propto t$).

questions.question: A car moves at a constant speed $v$ against a resistive force (drag) proportional to the square of its speed, $F_{drag} = bv^2$. What is the power required to maintain this speed?
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the net force is zero, so the engine's forward force must equal the drag force: $F_{engine} = bv^2$. Power is $P = F_{engine} v = (bv^2)(v) = bv^3$. This cubic relationship shows why high-speed driving requires dramatically more power.

questions.question: On a graph of Work ($W$) vs. Time ($t$), the slope of the tangent line at any point represents:
questions.explanation: Since $P = \frac{dW}{dt}$, the derivative of the work-time function is the instantaneous power. Graphically, the derivative at a point is the slope of the tangent line to the curve at that point.

questions.question: A $1000$ kg elevator rises at a constant speed of $2$ m/s. What is the power delivered by the tension in the cable? ($g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At constant speed, net force is zero, so tension $T = mg = 1000 \times 10 = 10,000$ N. Power delivered by tension: $P = T \cdot v = (10,000 \text{ N}) \times (2 \text{ m/s}) = 20,000$ W. (Note: This is the power input; motor power might differ due to efficiency.)

questions.question: If the power delivered to a particle is constant, its kinetic energy $K$ as a function of time $t$ is:
questions.explanation: From $P = \frac{dK}{dt}$, if $P$ is constant, then $\frac{dK}{dt} = P \Rightarrow dK = P dt$. Integrating: $K(t) = Pt + K_0$, where $K_0$ is initial kinetic energy. Thus, kinetic energy increases linearly with time.

questions.question: An engine outputs $50$ kW of power while pulling a train at $25$ m/s. What is the pulling force exerted by the engine?
questions.explanation: Using $P = Fv$, solve for force: $F = \frac{P}{v} = \frac{50,000 \text{ W}}{25 \text{ m/s}} = 2,000$ N. This assumes all engine power is used for pulling against resistance at constant speed.

questions.question: A force $F$ acts on an object such that its position is $x(t) = t^3$. If $F$ is constant, the power $P$ is proportional to:
questions.explanation: Velocity: $v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = 3t^2$. Power: $P(t) = F v(t) = F(3t^2) = 3F t^2$. Since $F$ is constant, $P \propto t^2$.

questions.question: The unit 'Watt' is equivalent to which of the following?
questions.explanation: 1 Watt = 1 Joule/second = 1 (N·m)/s. Since 1 N = 1 kg·m/s², we have: 1 W = (kg·m/s² · m) / s = kg·m²/s³. Option D (N·m) is Joule, not Watt.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of power concepts and calculus relationships. You can compute instantaneous power via dot products and derivatives, analyze power in constant acceleration and drag situations, extract force from power-velocity data, and understand dimensional analysis.
scoreMessages.70: Strong analytical skills. Review: the connection $P = dW/dt$ and its graphical meaning, power requirements for constant velocity against drag ($P \propto v^3$), and solving for force when given power and velocity.
scoreMessages.50: Good foundational understanding. Focus on: memorizing $P = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{v}$ and $P = dW/dt$, applying power formulas to elevator/train problems, and recognizing linear vs. quadratic power-time relationships.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the definition: Power = rate of doing work. Practice simple calculations like $P = Fv$ for constant force and velocity, then progress to derivatives and dot products.
